questions.text: A 26-year-old man is being treated with chemotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma. During his treatment, he has severe vomiting. Which of the following areas of the brain is responsible for multiple episodes of vomiting?
questions.solution:
• Area postrema is known as chemoreceptor trigger zone and leads to severe vomiting episodes. It is a B shaped band of tissue on lateral walls of fourth ventricle near the obex. It lies outside the blood brain barrier and hence can be irritated by chemotherapeutic drugs.
  • Lesions of area postrema have little effects on vomiting response of GI irritation or motion sickness. But they abolish the vomiting that occurs following injection of apomorphine. Such lesions also decrease vomiting in uraemia and radiation sickness.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman has a progressive neurological disorder resulting in degeneration of the anterior horn cells throughout her spinal cord and brainstem. Which of the following abnormal movements is she most likely to exhibit?
questions.solution:
• Anterior horn cells in spinal cord are part of lower motor neuron circuit. Axons that start from these cells terminate on skeletal muscle.
  • Damage to these neurons is associated with flaccid paralysis, muscular atrophy and fasciculation.
  • Fasciculations are visible muscle twitches that appear as flickers under the skin.
  • Muscles tone is reduced in these patients leading to flaccid paralysis.

questions.text: A child was defecating in open air in village when he was attacked by pack of dogs. One of the attaching dogs was found dead the next day. Considering the high risk of rabies in the child he has admitted to District hospital and was given ant rabies serum (ARS) and Rabipur vaccine which of the following is responsible for transport of rabies virus to brain?
questions.solution:
• The Rabies virus travels via the axons of nerve retrogradely towards the brain. The molecular motor responsible for this retrograde transport is Dynein.
  • Kinesin is responsible for anterograde movement.
  • Microinvasive virus, such as alpha herpesvirus (αHV) and rabies virus (RABV), initially infect peripheral tissue, followed by invasion of the innervating axon terminal. Virus particles now undergo long distance retrograde axonal transport to reach the neuron cells bodies in the peripheral or central nervous system.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient has complaints of breathlessness on climbing stairs. On auscultation heart sounds are normal and normal breath sounds are heard in bilateral lung fields. Flow volume loop is shown/marked in color blue.

Comment on diagnosis?
questions.solution: • The image shown a flow volume curve marked in color blue that is shifted to left and has lesser surface area covered as compared to baseline which is marked in color dotted green. Since the Residual volume and Total lung capacity in curve is reduced it implies patient is having parenchymal restrictive lung disease.

choices.text: Using energy in ATP to extrude 3Na+ out of cellsin exchange for taking two K+ into the cell
Using energy in ATP to extrude 3K+ out of cells in exchange for taking Na+ into the cell
Using the energy in moving Na+ into the cell or K+outside the cells to make ATP
Using energy in moving Na+ outside of cells or K+ inside the cell to make ATP

questions.text: The electrogenic Na/K ATPase plays a critical role in cellular physiology by?
questions.solution:
• Na+ K+ ATPase catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP to adenosine diphosphate and uses energy to extrude three Na+ from the cells and take tow K+ into the cell for each molecule of ATP hydrolyzed.
  • It is therefore said to have a coupling ratio of 3:2
  • Its activity is inhibited by Ouabain an related digitalis glycosides which are used for CHF.
  • Active transport of sodium and potassium is a major energy consuming process in the body in body it accounts for 4% of energy utilized by cells and 70% of energy utilized by neurons.

choices.text: Carbohydrate malabsorption due to mucosal disorder
Carbohydrate malabsorption die to chronic pancreatitis
Fat malabsorption due to mucosal disorder
Fat malabsorption due to chronic pancreatitis

questions.text: A 41-year-old patient presented with chronic diarrhea from last 3 months. AD xylose absorption test will reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Xylose is a pentose sugar and is absorbed directly from intestinal mucosa
  • D xylose will reveal carbohydrate malabsorption due to mucosal disorder, but in malabsorption due to pancreatic disease, the D-xylose test should be normal.
  • Due to high false positive and ease of obtaining small intestinal biopsy after endoscopy, intestinal biopsy is the preferred method.

questions.text: Which hormone receptor has 4 subunits and 2 units for tyrosine kinase receptor binding?
questions.solution: • Insulin receptor is a tetramer made of two alpha and two beta glycoprotein protein. The alpha subunits bind insulin and are extracellular while beta subunits have tyrosine kinase activity. The growth promoting anabolic effects of insulin are mediated by phosphatidyl inositol kinase pathway.

choices.text: Apnea followed by Rapid shallow breathing
Hyperpnea followed by raid shallow breathing

questions.text: Damage to J receptors in lungs will result in?
questions.solution:
• Since the C fiberendings are close to pulmonary vessels they are called as J (Juxta-capillary) receptors.
  • They are simulated by hyperinflation of the lung
  • Activation of chemo-sensitive vagal V fibers in the cardio-pulmonary region causes profound bradycardia, hypotension and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called as pulmonary chemo-reflex. Hering breur reflexes ae mediated by vagal afferent activity is mediated by slowly adapting receptors and causes shortening of inspiration.
  • Hering Breur inflation reflex is an increase in duration of expiration produced by steady lung inflation
  • Hering Breur deflation reflex is a decrease in duration of expiration produced by marked deflation of lung.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding surfactant, surface tension and collapse of alveoli are true?
a. Surfactant is produced by type 2 alveolar cells
b. Type 2 alveolar cells constitutes 90% of alveolar surface
c. The most important components are the phospholipid dipalmitoyl phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine surfactant apoprotein and calcium ions.
d. Surface tension and elastic recoil forces both help in collapsing of alveoli
e. Pressure = 2* surface tension/radius of alveolus
questions.solution:
• Surfactant is a surface-active agent in water, that greatly reduces the surface tensions of water
  • It is secreted by special surfactant secreting epithelial cells called type 2 alveolar epithelial cells, which constitute about 10 percent of the surface area of the alveoli
  • These cells are granular, containing lipid inculsions that are secreted in the surfactant into the alveoli
  • Surfactant is a complex mixture of several phospholipid, protein and ions
  • The important components are:
    • Phospholipids dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine
    • Surfactant apoproteins
    • Calcium ions
  • The dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine and several important phospholipids are responsible for reducing the surface tensions
  • Surface tension does not allow collapse of alveoli while elastic recoil can help in collapse
  • P=RT/R which means, Pressure + 2x Surface tension/radius of alveolus

choices.text: a, b, c, d, e, f

questions.text:
A 36-year-old Covid 19 patient came to ER with shortness of breath and on examination his SpO2 was 92%. The oxygen dissociation curves deviation from normal to left. Which of the other conditions from the following options will deviated the oxygen dissociation curve on same side as this patient?
a. Low CO2
b. High CO2
c. Low pH
d. High pH
e. Low blood temperature
f. High blood temperature
questions.solution:
• the sigmoid shaped oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left, due to induces respiratory alkalosis (drop in partial pressure of CO2) because of hypoxemia driven tachypnea in Covid 19


Factors that cause Shifts to left:

i. Decreased hydrogen ions 9high pH)

ii. Decrease CO2

iii. Decrease temperature

iv. Decreased BPG

Factors that cause Shift to right:

i. Increased hydrogen ions (low pH)

ii. Increased CO2

iii. Increased temperature

iv. Increased BPG

choices.text: Pacemaker cells are present in proximal stomach

questions.text: True about basic electrical rhythm of GIT:
questions.solution:
Basic Electrical Rhythm

  • Except in the esophagus and the proximal portion of the stomach, the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract has spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in membrane potential between about -65 and -45 mV – Basic electric rhythm (BER), also known as slow wave potentials.
  • BER is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells.
  • In the stomach and small intestine, there is a descending gradient in pacemaker frequency
  • BER itself rarely causes muscle contraction, but spike potentials superimposed on the most depolarizing portions of the BER waves do increase muscle tension.
  • The depolarization portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K= efflux
  • Many polypeptides and neurotransmitters effect the BER. For example, acetylcholine increases the number of spikers and the tensions of the smooth muscle, where as epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and the tensions.
  • The rate of the BER is about 4/min in the stomach. It is about 12/min in the duodenum and falls to about 8/min in the distal ileum. In the colon, the BER rate rises from about 2/min at the cecum to about 6/min a the sigmoid.
  • The function of BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation; contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, e.g. persistent in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

questions.text: A patient with Pulmonary vascular disease has mean pulmonary arterial and venous pressure of 54- and 6-mm Hg respectively. The cardiac output of this patient is 4 liters per minute. What is the Pulmonary vascular resistance?
questions.solution: Pulmonary vascular resistance = (input pressure output pressure)/blood flow=(54-6)/4 = 48/4 =12

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Sildenafil: it is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodeasterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.
  • Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.text: What is the clearance (ml/min) of a substance x if its plasma concentration is 10mg/mL, in urine is 100mg/mL and urine flow is 2ml/min?
questions.solution:
• Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time.
  • It is calculated by the formula:


  • C= clearance (mL/min)
  • [U]x= Urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL) = 100 mg/mL
  • V= Urine flow rate per minute (mL/min) = 2mL/min
  • [P]x = Plasma concentration of substance (mg/mL) = 10 mg/mL
  • Substituting the values

choices.text: It is a form of titanopathy
Muscle wasting occurs in the pelvic region only
It is an X-linked recessive disorder
Skeletal muscle wasting occurs due to abnormalities of the contractile filaments

questions.text: True about Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is:
questions.solution:
• Duchenne's muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder. (Option A is correct) There is a genetic defect in the dystrophin gene; it results in deficiency of the protein dystrophin in skeletal muscle (and in some other tissues such as smooth muscle, brain, etc.)
  • Dystrophin is a large protein that is present on the intracellular surface of the skeletal muscle membrane (sarcolemma); along with other integral membrane glycoproteins, it makes dystrophin-glycoprotein complex. This complex provides stability to the sarcolemma by creating a link between cytoskeleton of the muscle cells and the extracellular matrix. It prevents contraction induced injury or rupture of the muscle.
  • In DMD, there is severe muscle wasting; death may occur form respiratory failure.
  • Muscle wasting in the pelvic region is seen in limb-girdle muscular dystrophy may occurs due to a defect in sarcolemma repair; loss/mutation of the protein dystrophin may be responsible.
  • Defects in the protein titin are termed titanopathies. Example- Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy 2J, tibial muscular dystrophy, etc. Titin is a protein that maintains alignment ofthe thick filaments in the sarcomere. It may also serve as a mechanosensory and influence gene expression and protein degradation in a mechanical activity-dependent manner.

questions.text: Before the onset of puberty, the GnRH neurons are under the inhibitory control of:
questions.solution:
• The transition to a reproductive state (during puberty) requires maturation of the entire hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Before this maturation occurs, plasma LH and FSH levels are diminished despite low concentration of gonadal steroids and inhibin. Therefore, either the negative feedback system is inoperative or restrained by other CNS input to the GnRH neurons, or the hypothalamus and pituitary are exquisitely sensitive to testosterone, estradiol, and inhibin.
  • GnRH neurons are said to be under inhibitory influence of GABAergic neurons. additional inhibition comes form NPY, endorphins, and nocturnal melatonin secretion. Endorphin inhibition does not seem to be essential, because opioid antagonists do not increase LH or FSH levels during childhood before puberty. Hence, option C is more appropriate. Also, sensitivity of hypothalamus and pituitary to circulating gonadal steroids and inhibin is decrease. Hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis becomes functional/matured. Pulsatile GnRH secretion coincides with the onset of puberty.
  • There is no clinically evident event that precipitates onset of puberty. Probably, there is a preprogrammed schedule of expression of genes.

choices.text: Impermeable in the loop of Henle
It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

questions.text: A substance is present in a concertation of 2 mg% in the afferent arteriole and zero mg% in the efferent. True about the substance is:
questions.solution: • This is only a hypothetical situation. Filtration fraction is about 20%. It means, of the total plasma passing through the glomerulus per unit time, about 20% is filtered out. If a substance has zero concentration in the efferent arteriole, it means all of that substance was freely and completely filtered out in the plasma that has formed the glomerular filtrate.

questions.text: One gram of mannitol was injected into a woman. After equilibration, a plasma sample has a mannitol concentration of 0.08 g/L. during the equilibration period, 20% of the injected mannitol was excreted in the urine. The woman's
questions.solution: • Mannitol is a marker substance for the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume. ECF volume= amount of mannitol/concentration of mannitol = 1 g - 0.2 g/0.08 g/L = 10 L

questions.text: A patient with a family H/O peripheral neuropathy is found to have a decrease in nerve conduction velocity and an X-linked mutation of connexin 32, suggesting the diagnosis of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. Connexin is an important component of which of the following?
questions.solution: • Connexin is a membrane-spanning protein that is used to create gap junction channel. The channel is called connexon. Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease comprises a heterogenous group of inherited peripheral neuropathies. Mutation of the connexin 32 is one example. Connexin 32 is located in the folds of the Schwann cell cytoplasm around the nodes of Ranvier.

choices.text: Closure of calcium channels at the presynaptic membrane
Opening of potassium channels at the presynaptic membrance
Closure of sodium channels at the postsynaptic membrane
Opening of calcium channels at the postsynaptic membrane

questions.text: By which of the following mechanism does the botulinum toxin block neuromuscular transmission?
questions.solution:
• Botulinum toxin (the most toxic substance known) is a protease that cleaves proteins involved in the release of acetylcholine at the myoneural presynaptic junction, causing flaccid paralysis. This happens with the closure of calcium channels at the presynaptic membrane.
  • Tetanus toxin cause spastic paralysis by blocking presynaptic inhibitory neurotransmitter (glycine and GABA) release in the CNS, and botulism cause flaccid paralysis's by blocking the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Notes:
    • Botulinum toxins B, D, F, and G act on synaptobrevin.
    • Botulinum toxin C acts on syntaxin.
    • Botulinum toxins A and E act on SNAP-25.
  • Synaptobrevin, syntaxin and SNAP_25 are proteins involved in neurotransmitter release.

questions.text: The pathway of which system crosses in the ventral white commissure of the spinal cord within a few segments of entry and then curses to the thalamus contralateral to the side of the body from which the signal originated?
questions.solution: • Fibers in the anterolateral system cross in the anterior white commissure within a few segments of their entry before ascending on the contralateral side. Signals ascending in the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system do not cross until they reach th dorsal column nuclei in the medulla.

choices.text: ARTERIOVENOUS DIFFERENCE IN OXYGEN CONCENTRATION REMAINS CONSTANT
ACTIVITY OF JOINT PROPRIOCEPTORS IS IMPORTANT FACTOR ININCREASING VENTILATION

questions.text: ACCORDING TO YOU, WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING STATEMENTS ARE TRUE IN CORRESPONDENCE TO RESPIRATORY ADJUSTMENTS DURING EXERCISE?
questions.solution:
THE FOLLOWING CHANGES ARE SEEN DURING EXERCISE.

DURING STRENOUS EXERCISE OXYGEN CONSUMPTION AND CARBONDIOXIDE GENERATION INCREASES TO AS MUCH AS 20 FOLDS.

  • THE ARTERIAL PO2, PCO2 AND PH USUALLY REMAINS EXACTLY NORMAL.
  • PART OF THIS STIMULATION OF THE ALVEOLAR VENTILATION RESULTS FROM DIRECT STIMULATION OF THE RESPIRATORY CENTRE BY THE NERVOUS SYSTEM. AND FROM THE SENSORY SIGNALS TRANSMITTED FROM CONTRACTING MUSCLE AND JOINT PROPRIOCEPTORS
  • DURING STRENOUS EXERCISE THE UTILISATION OF OXYGEN INCREASES TO 75%-85%. SO ESSENTIALLY ALL THE OXYGEN IS GIVEN TO THE EXERCISING MUSCLE LEADING TO INCREASED ARTERIO VENOUS DIFFERENCE IN OXYGEN CONCENTRATION.

questions.text: THE FIBRES FROM THE CONTRALATERAL NASAL PART OF THE RETINA PROJECT TO THE FOLLOIWNG LAYERS OF THE LATERAL GENICULATE BODY IN OPTIC PATHWAY?
questions.solution:
• ON EACH SIDE LAYER 1,4,6 OF THE LATERAL GENICULATE NUCLEUS RECEIVE INPUT FROM THE CONTRALATERAL EYE
  • WHEREAS LAYERS 2, 3 AND 5 RECEIVE INPUT FROM THE IPISILATERAL EYE

questions.text: Which is a true statement regarding inhibin?
questions.solution:
Inhibin is secreted by the sertoli cells in males and by the granulosa cells in females.

It inhibits the secretion of Gonadotrophin Releasing Hormone.

It is a glycoprotein with molecular weight between 10,000 and 30,000.

It has potent inhibitory feedback effect on the anterior pituitary gland which in turn provides negative feedback mechanism for the control of spermatogenesis.

Ref: Textbook of Medical Physiology, Guyton and Hall, 11th edition, page 1007.

questions.text: Pulmonary compliance is not decreased in
questions.solution: Pulmonary compliance is increased in emphysema (a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). In the other 3 conditions (Decreased surfactant production, Pulmonary congestion and Pulmonary fibrosis), the pulmonary compliance is decreased.

questions.text: A newly posted junior doctor had difficulty in finding out base deficit/excess for blood in a given patient. An experienced senior resident advised a quick method to determine acid base composition of blood based on PCO2. Which of the following is the likely method he suggested to predict acid base composition of blood?
questions.solution: Siggard Andersen normogram helps to predict the acid base status of blood. PCO2 is plotted in the Y axis and pH in the X axis.

choices.text: Increase in the sensitivity of central chemoreceptors
Increase in the sensitivity of carotid body to hypoxia
Shift in the oxygen dissociation curve to the left

questions.text: During acclimatization to high altitude all of the following take place except:
questions.solution: During acclimatization, there is shift of oxygen dissociation curve to the right. This improves oxygen release into tissues.

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS THE PREDOMINANT ESTROGEN IN THE PLASMA OF THE PREMENOPAUSAL PREGNANT WOMEN ?
questions.solution:
ESTRADIOL ARE ABUNDANTLY SECRETED FROM OVARY. THEY ARE THE PREDOMINANT TYPE OF ESTROGEN IN PREMENOPAUSAL WOMEN.

  • ESTRONE IS SYNTHESIZED IN ADIPOSE TISSUE. THEY ARE THE PREDOMINANT TYPE OF ESTROGEN IN POSTMENOPAUSAL WOMEN.
  • ESTRIOL IS THE PREDOMINANT FORM OF ESTROGEN IN THE PREGNANT WOMEN.

questions.text: The parvocellular pathway from lateral geniculate nucleus to visual cortex is most sensitive for the stimulus of:
questions.solution:
Parvocellular pathway-Color vision, texture, shape, fine detail

Magnocellular pathway - Detection of movement, depth, flickers

choices.text: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

questions.text: All of the following development events are dependent on the production of maternal or fetal glucocorticoid, except:
questions.solution:
• Functions of maternal/fetal corticosteroids in the fetus:
    • Synthesis of surfactant in the lungs
    • Induction of thymic involution
    • Proper development of hypothalamopituitary axis

choices.text: Reabsorption of Na+ in thick ascending limb
Action of ADH via aquaporin channels

questions.text: The prime driving force for counter current multiplier system is:
questions.solution: The primary driving force is reabsorption of Na+ in thick ascending limb. Medullary hyperosmolarity is an effect produced by the counter current multiplier system

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS NOT A MEDIAL PATHWAY INVOLVED IN MAINTENANCE OF POSTURE ?
questions.solution:
• THE RUBROSPINAL PATHWAY IS A PART OF LATERAL BRAINSTEM PATHWAYS
  • THE MEDIAL BRAINSTEM PATHWAYS:
    • PONTINE AND MEDULLARY RETICULOSPINAL TRACT
    • VESTIBULOSPINAL TRACT
  • THESE PATHWAYS DESCEND IN THE IPSILATERAL VENTRAL COLUMNS OF THE SPINAL CORD AND TERMINATE PREDOMINANTLY IN THE INTER NEURONS IN THE VENTROMEDIAL PART OF THE VENTRAL HORN TO CONTROL AXIAL AND PROXIMAL MUSCLES
  • THE LATERAL BRAINSTEM PATHWAYS :
    • THE CORTICOSPINAL TRACT
    • RUBROSPINAL TRACT
  • THEY CROSS THE MIDLINE AND PROJECT TO INTERNEURONS IN THE DOSROLATERAL PART OF SPINAL VENTRAL HORN TO ALSO INFLUENCE THE MOTOR NEURONS THAT CONTROL THE DISTAL LIMB MUSCLES.
  • THE RUBROSPINAL TRACT EXCITES FLEXOR MOTOR NEURONS AND INHIBIT EXTENSOR MOTOR NEURONS
  • THIS PATHWAY MAY PLAY ROLE IN POSTURE TYPICAL OF DECORTICATE RIGIDITY.

choices.text: THIS IS CHARACTERISTIC OF A STATE IN WHICH DECREASED GAMMA MOTOR NEURON DISCHARGE IS SEEN
THE STRECTH REFLEX -INVERSE STRETCH REFLEX SEQUENCE MAY CONTRIBUTE TO THIS RESPONSE
ONLY SUSTAINED CLONUS WITH 5 OR MORE BEATS IS CONSIDERED ABNORMAL
CLONUS MAY ALSO OCCUR IN THE SPINAL CORD INJURY THAT DISRUPTS THE DESCENDING CORTICAL INPUT TO SPINAL GLYCINERGIC INHIBITORY INTERNEURON CALLED AS RENSHAW INHIBITION

questions.text: A 67 yr OLD HYPERTENSIVE WOMEN WAS BROUGHT TO THE EMERGENCY BY HER SON WITH COMPLAINTS OF SPASTICITY IN BOTH THE LOWER LIMBS. FURTHER NEUROLOGICAL EXAMINATION REVEALS REGULAR REPETITIVE RYHTMIC CONTRACTION OF A MUSCLE SUBJECTED TO SUDDEN MAINTAINED STRETCH. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE REGARDING THIS PHENOMENON ?
questions.solution:
• IT IS A CASE OF CLONUS. A CHARACTERISTIC OF STATE IN WHICH INCREASED GAMMA MOTOR NEURON DISCHARGE IS PRESENT IS CLONUS
  • WHEN A MUSCLE IS SUBJECTED TO SUDDEN MAINTAINED STRETCH, THERE OCCURS REGULAR, REPETITIVE AND RYHTMIC CONTRACTIONS. THIS IS CALLED CLONUS.

choices.text: LUNG DAMAGE IS CAUSED BY AIR EMBOLISM
PAIN IN THE JOINT IS DUE TO NITROGEN BUBBLES
TREMORS ARE SEEN DUE TO NITROGEN NARCOSIS
HIGH PRESSURE NERVOUS SYNDROME CAN BE PREVENTED BY USING MIXTURE OF OXYGEN AND HELIUM

questions.text: REGARDING THE CAISSONS DISEASE WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING STATEMENTS IS CORRECT ?
questions.solution:
DECOMPRESSION SICKENESS:

AS THE DIVER BREATHING 80% NITROGEN ASCENDS FROM DIVE, THE ELEVATED ALVEOLAR PN2 FALLS. N2 DIFFUSES FROM THE TISSUES INTO LUNG OWING TO PRESSURE GRADIENT.

IF RETURN TO THE ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE IS GRADUAL, NO HARMFUL EFFECTS ARE SEEN.

BUT IF THE ASCENT IS RAPID NITROGEN ESCAPES AND FORM BUBBLES IN THE TISSUES AND BLOOD LEADING TO THE SYMPTOMS OF DECOMPRESSION SICKNESS.

BUBBLES IN THE TISSUES CAUSE SEVER PAIN ESPECIALLY AROUND JOINTS. AND NEUROLOGICAL SYMPTOMS LIKE PARESTHESIA AND ITCHING.

questions.text: CEREBRAL BLOOD FLOW IS REGULATED BY ALL OF THE FOLLOWING EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
• FACTORS AFFECTING OVERALL CEREBRAL BLOOD FLOW:
    • INTRACRANIAL PRESSURE
    • LOCAL CONSTRICTION AND DILATATION OF CEREBRAL ARTERIOLES
    • VISCOSITY OF BLOOD
    • MEAN ARTERIAL PRESSURE AT BRAIN LEVEL
    • THE MOST IMPORTANT EXTRINSIC INFLUENCES ON CEREBRAL BLOOD FLOW ARE THE RESPIRATORY GASES TENSION PARTICULARLY ARTERIAL PCO2.
  • CEREBRAL BLOOD FLOW IS DIRECTLY PROPORTIONAL TO ARTERIAL PCO2 BETWEEN 20 AND 80 MM OF HG

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS REFERRED TO AS THE WINDOW OF THE LIMBIC SYSTEM ?
questions.solution:
• THE AMYGDALA HAS BEEN CALLED AS THE WINDOW THROUGH WHICH THE LIMBIC SYSTEM SEES THE PLACE OF THE PERSON IN THE WORLD
  • THE AMYGDALA RECEIVES THE NEURONAL SIGNALS FROM ALL THE PORTIONS OF THE LIMBIC CORTEX AS WELL AS FROM THE NEOCORTEX OF THE TEMPORAL, PARIETAL AND OCCIPITAL LOBES ESPECIALLY FROM THE AUDITORY AND VISUAL ASSOCIATION AREAS.

questions.text: IN A 100 M DASH RACE MOST OF THE ENERGY CONSUMED BY THE SKELETAL MUSCLE TO REPLENISH THE ATP IS DERIVED FROM ?
questions.solution: • IN 100 M DASH RACE THAT USUALLY TAKES 10 SEC, 85% OF THE ENERGY CONSUMED IS DERIVED ANAERIBICALLY BY PHOSPHOCREATINE, WHICH IS HYDROLYSED TO CREATINE AND PHOSPHATE GROUPS WITH THE RELEASE OF CONSIDERABLE AMOUNT OF ENERGY.

questions.text: A PATIENT WITH CARDIAC OUTPUT OF 5L/MIN AND BODY SURFACE AREA OF 1.7m2. WHAT WILL BE THE CARDIAC INDEX IN (L/MIN/m2)?
questions.solution:
CARDIAC INDEX IS THE CARDIAC OUTPUT PER MINUTE PER SQUARE METER OF BODY SURFACE AREA

  • CARDIAC INDEX =CARDIAC OUTPUT/BODY SURFACE AREA
  • THEREFORE CARDIAC INDEX =5L/MIN/1.7m2

 =2.9L

questions.text: ON INFUSION OF LARGE VOLUME OF BLOOD, THE MAP RISES FROM 100 MM OF HG TO 175 MM OF HG. DUE TO BARORECEPTOR MECHANISM THE MAP FALLS TO 125MMOF HG. CALCULATE THE GAIN OF THE FEEDBACK SYSTEM ?
questions.solution:
• THE GAIN OF THE FEEDBACK SYSTEM IN THE ABOVE CASE IS -2
  • GAIN =C/E
  • C-CORRECTION ACHIEVED FROM THE DEVIATED VALUE

E-REMAINING ERROR POST CORRECTION

THE ORIGINAL VALUE IN THE GIVEN CASE IS 100MM OF HG

THE DEVIATED VALUE IN THE GIVEN CASE IS 175 MM OF HG

THE CORRECTED VALUE IN THE GIVEN CASE IN 125 MM OF HG

C=CORRECTED VALUE -DEVIATED VALUE

=125-175

=-50 MM OF HG

E= CORRECTED VALUE – ORIGINAL VALUE

=125-100

=25MM HG

>GAIN =-50/25MMHG

=-2

questions.text: A 60 KG ADULT MALE HAS A HEMATOCRIT READING OF 40 AND A PLASMA VOLUME OF 3L. WHAT IS HIS TOTAL BLOOD VOLUME IN LITRES ?
questions.solution:
TOTAL BLOOD VOLUME =PLASMA VOLUME/1-HEMATOCRIT

                                             =3L/1-O.4

                                              =5 LITRE

questions.text: A DYE X WHICH MEASURES THE PLASMA VOLUME IS REPLACED BY DYE Y WHICH CAN DIFFUSE OUT OF THE CAPILLARIES.WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS TRUE REGADING THE NEWLY MEASURED PLASMA VOLUME ?
questions.solution:
• AS THE DYE DIFFUSES OUT OF THE CAPILLARIES THE MEASURED CONCENTRATION OF THE DYE AFTER EQUILIBRIUM WILL BE LESS.
  • SO AS PER THE FORMULA, THE VOLUME MEASURED WILL BE FALSELY HIGH

V=(AMOUNT INJECTED -AMOUNT EXCRETED)/PLASMA CONCENTRATION OF THE DYE

choices.text: A FIBRES ARE MORE SENSITIVE TO PRESSURE THAN C FIBRES
B FIBRES ARE MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO PRSSURE THAN A FIBRES
C FIBRES ARE MORE SENSITIVE TO PRSSURE THAN A FIBRES
MOTOR NERVES ARE MORE AFFECTED BY SLEEP THAN SENSORY NERVES

questions.text: A MAN FALLS INTO DEEP SLEEP WITH ONE ARM UNDER HIS HEAD. HE FINDS HE WAS UNABLE TO MOVE THIS ARM WHEN HE AWAKENS. THE ARM TINGLES AND THE PAIN SENSATION IS STILL INTACT. WHAT IS THE REASON FOR THE LOSS OF MOTOR FUNCTION WITHOUT LOSS OF PAIN SENSATION ?
questions.solution:
THE REASON FOR THE LOSS OF MOTOR FUNCTION WITHOUT LOSS OF PAIN SENSATION IS A FIBRES ARE MORE SENSITIVE TO PRESSURE THAN C FIBRES.

SLEEPING FOR A LONG PERIOD WITH ARMS UNDER THE HEAD PUTS PRESSURE ON A NERVE, LEADING TO LOSS OF CONDUCTION IN A LARGE DIAMETER MOTOR TOUCH AND PRESSURE FIBRES, WHILE PAIN SENSATION REMAINS RELATIVELY INTACT.

THE SUSCEPTIBILITY OF A NERVE FIBRE TO PRESSURE ARE A>B>C

questions.text: THE BULBORETICULAR FACILITATORY AREA OF BRAINSTEM EXCITES THE GAMMA EFFERENT SYSTEM. THIS BULBORETICUALR AREA RECEIVES IMPULSE FROM WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING AREAS?
questions.solution:
IMPULSE ARE TRANSMITTED INTO THE BULBORETICULAR AREA FROM:

  • CEREBRAL CORTEX
  • CEREBELLUM
  • BASAL GANGLIA

THE GAMMA EFFERENT SYSTEM IS EXCITIED BY SIGNALS FROM THE BULBORETICULAR FACILITATORY REGION OF THE BRAINSTEM

ANY TIME A PERSON MUST PERFORM A MUSCLE FUNCTION THAT REQUIRES A HIGH DEGREE OF DELICATE AND EXACT POSITIONING,THE BULBORETICULAR FACILITATORY REGION OF THE BRAINSTEM.

questions.text: EXCESSIVE CITRATE IN TRANSFUSED BLOOD CAN CAUSE WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING ABNORMALITIES ?
questions.solution:
CITRATE METABOLISM TO BICARBONATE CAN CONTRIBUTE TO METABOLIC ALKALOSIS, WHERE AS BINDING OF CALCIUM BY CITRATE COULD RESULT IN HYPOCALCEMIA

INDEED METABOLIC ALKALOSIS RATHER THAN METABOLIC ACIDOSIS COULD FOLLOW AFTER A MASSIVE BLOOD TRANSFUSION.

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS MOST APPROPRIATE FOR A FEMALE SUFFERIN FROM INSULIN DEPENDENT DIABETES MELLITUS WITH A PH OF 7.2.PCO2-20MM HG, HCO3 -17MMOL/L
questions.solution:
• Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is an acute metabolic complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, hyperketonemia, and metabolic acidosis. Hyperglycemia causes an osmotic diuresis with significant fluid and electrolyte loss.
  • DKA occurs mostly in type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • WITHOUT ENOUGH INSULIN BODY TRIES TO BREAKDOWN FATS AS FUEL.THIS PROCESS PRODUCES BUILDUP OF ACIDS IN THE BODY STREAM KNOWN AS KETONES.
  • It causes nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain and can progress to cerebral edema, coma, and death.

questions.text: A 23 YEAR OLD WOMAN COMPLAINS OF ABDOMINAL CRAMPS AND BLOATING THAT IS RELIEVED BY DEFECATION .SUBSEQUENT CLINICAL EVALUATION REVEALS AN INCREASED MAXIMUM ACID OUTPUT,DECREASED SERUM CALCIUM AND IRON CONCENTRATION AND MICROCYTIC ANEMIA .INFLAMMATION IN WHICH AREA OF GI TRACT EXPLAINS THESE FINDINGS?
questions.solution:
• INFALMMATION OF DUODENUM MAY LEAD TO INCREASED ACID OUTPUT, MICROCYTIC ANEMIA AND HYPOCALCEMIA
  • INCREASED BASAL AND MAXIMUM ACID OUTPUT MAY RESULT FROM EXCESSIVE STIMULATON OF THE PARIETAL CELL OR REDUCED INHIBITORY FEEDBACK.
  • THE LATTER MAY OCCUR WHEN THE PROXIMAL SMALL INTESTINE IS INFLAMMED.
  • ALTHOUGH CALCIUM IS ABSORBED ALONG THE ENTIRE LENGTH OF THE SMALL INTESTINE ,IT IS ABSORBED PRIMARILY IN THE DUODENUM.
  • SIMILARLY IRON IS ABSORBED PRIMARILY IN THE DUODENUM,MICROCYTIC HYPOCHROMIC ANEMIA IS THE RESULT OF REDUCED STORES OF IRON.

choices.text: IT IS INHIBITED BY THE PRESENCE OF AMINOACIDS IN THE DUODENUM
IT IS INHIBITED BY A FAT RICH MEAL
IT OCCURS IN RESPONSE TO CHOLECYSTOKININ

questions.text: A 42 YR OLD WOMAN PRESENTS TO THE EMERGENCY ROOM WITH RIGH UPPER QUADRANT PAIN THAT DEVELOPED AFTER DINNER. SHE IS DIAGNOSED AS HAVING CHOLECYSTITIS. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING WOULD BE EXPECTED WITH CONTRACTION OF GALL BLADDER FOLLOWING A MEAL ?
questions.solution:
• CHOLECYSTOKININ IS RELEASED FROM THE UPPER SMALL INTESTINE IN RESPONSE TO PARTIALLY HYDROLYSED DIETARY LIPIDS AND PROTEINS AND PROMOTES GALL BLADDER EMPTYING.
  • GALL BLADDER CONTRACTION AND SPINCHTER OF ODDI RELAXATION ARE NECESSARY FRO DELIVERY OF BILE INTO THE DUODENUM
  • THESE MUSCULAR ACTIONS ARE BOTH UNDER HORMONAL AND NEURAL CONTROL
  • GALL BLADDER CONTRACTION IS ALSO PROMOTED BY VAGAL STIMULATION WHICH IS CHOLINERGICALLY MEDIATED AND BLOCKED BY THE MUSCARINIC RECEPTOR ANTAGONIST, ATROPINE.

questions.text: WHEN THE RESPIRATORY DRIVE FOR INCREASED PULMONARY VENTILATION IS GREATER THAN NORMAL, A SPECIAL SET OF RESPIRATORY NEURONS THAT ARE INACTIVE DURING NORMAL QUIET BREATHING THEN BECOMES ACTIVE, CONTRIBUTING TO THE RESPIRATORY DRIVE. THESE NEURONS ARE LOCATED IN WHICH STRUCTURE ?
questions.solution:
• THE BASIC RHYTHM OF THE RESPIRATION IS GENERATED IN THE DORSAL RESPIRATORY GROUP OF NEURONS WHICH IS LOCATED ALMOST ENTIRELY IN THE NUCLEUS OF THE TRACTUS SOLITARIUS.
  • WHEN THE RESPIRATORY DRIVE FOR INCREASED PULMONARY VENTILATION BECOMES GREATER THAN NORMAL, THE RSPIRATORY SIGNAL SPILLS OVER INTO VENTRAL RESPIRATORY NEURONS, CAUSING THE VENTRAL RESPIRATORY AREA TO CONTRIBUTE TO RESPIRATORY DRIVE
  • HOWEVER NEURONS OF THE VENTRAL RESPIRATORY GROUP REMAINS ALMOST TOTALLY INACTIVE DURING NORMAL QUIET BREATHING .

questions.text: AN INJURY TO THE LATERAL PORTION OF POST CENTRAL GYRUS IN THE RIGHT HEMISPHERE WOULD RESULT IN SOME LOSS OF SENSATION IN THE ?
questions.solution:
• EACH HEMISPHERE RECEIVES SOMATOSENSORY INFORMATION FROM THE OPPPOSITE SIDE OF THE BODY IN THE POSTCENTRAL GYRUS
  • THE LATERAL PORTION OF THE POSTCENTRAL GYRUS RECEIVES SOMATOSENSORY INFORMATION FROM THE FACE AND NECK REGION.
  • WHILE THE MEDIAL PORTION OF THE POSTCENTRAL GYRUS RECEIVES SOMATOSENSORY INFROMATION FROM THE TRUNK AND APPENDAGES.
  • THUS IN THIS CASE INJURY TO THE LATERAL PORTION OF THE POSTCENTRAL GYRUS IN THE RIGHT HEMISPHERE WOULD RESULT IN LOSS OF SENSATION IN THE LEFT FACIAL AREA.

choices.text: RUNOFF OF BLOOD FROM THE AORTA TO THE ARTERIES

questions.text: THE PHYSIOLOGIC FUNCTION OF A RELATIVELY SLOW CONDUCTION THROUGH THE AV NODE IS TO ALLOW SUFFICIENT TIME FOR
questions.solution:
• THE ATRIOVENTRICULAR DELAY(WHICH CORRESPONDS TO PR INTERVAL) ALLOWS TIME FOR FILLING THE VENTRICLES FROM THE ATRIA.
  • IF THE VENTRICLES CONTRACTED BEFORE THEY FILLED, STROKE VOLUME WOULD DECREASE.
